author: Anonym
title: "Latest weather forecasts worrying": Meteorologists expect more rain in flood regions - The Limited Times
text:
Status: 29.12.2023, 18:46 PM
By: Bjarne Kommnick
CommentsPrint Share
Many regions of Germany are currently struggling against floods caused by storm "Zoltan". There is no improvement in sight, on the contrary: new rain is on the way.
Munich – The flood situation in Germany remains critical. In the past few days, experts were already expecting further rain at the turn of the year. This forecast now seems to be confirmed: In the flood areas, of all places, heavy downpours are expected to occur again at the turn of the year.
"Weather forecasts worrying": Despite flooding, no end to rain in sight for the time being Meteorologist Dominik Jung from wetter.net explains in a press release: "The latest weather forecasts are worrying." In the next 48 hours, the "high-resolution ICON-D2 model" from the German Weather Service (DWD) would expect 30 to 50 liters of precipitation per square meter, especially in the flood areas.
Will the situation in the flood areas come to a head at the turn of the year? According to the weather forecast, it probably is. Meteorologists announce new rain. (symbolic photo) © Sebastian Kahnert/dpa
Although water levels are currently falling again in many places, the outlook for the weather in the coming days could further exacerbate the situation. Especially over central Germany, where many dams are currently overflowing, the experts expect heavy precipitation until the end of the year.
And the experts also predict new masses of water in Germany in January: "The first ten days of January could bring 100 to 120 litres of rain in the west and south. The westerly weather situation simply does not want to end in the serious forecast period," says Jung. According to information from the DWD, the westerly weather situation (also known as "westerly exposure") describes a weather situation in which a strong west-to-east current develops over Europe over several days.
Weather in Germany: "Cold and snow don't stand a chance for the time being" Winter fans will probably go away empty-handed at the beginning of the year. "Cold and snow don't stand a chance in Germany for the time being. As a result, the risk of flooding remains very tense," predicts Jung. "In many cases, the dikes and dams are softening more and more, threatening to break. They are soaked by the rain and pressurized by the floods."
My news Thief fills 189 liters in canister reading
Discharged water from reservoir threatens places in Thuringia
The oldest butcher's shop in Germany comes from Baden-Württemberg read
Lake in Baden-Württemberg is the largest in the country – it is often overlookedread
Jetstream is heading for Germany: Current weather forecast makes people sit up and take noticeread
Flood situation critical: Lower Saxony calls on Bundeswehr for helpRead
Overall, it was particularly wet in 2023. According to a press release from the German Weather Service, this year was the sixth wettest year on record. At around 958 litres per square metre, more than 20 per cent more precipitation fell than in the reference period 1961 to 1990 (789 l/m²). November even turned out to be the second wettest since 1881.

author: Rachel Engel
title: Off-duty firefighters initiate rescue of Colo. skier after 2,000 feet fall
text:
Off-duty firefighters initiate rescue of Colo. skier after 2,000 feet fall
Firefighters in the Skywalker Couloir area saw the skier fall, called 911 and descended to reach the injured man
By Nicole Dorfman
Daily Camera
BOULDER COUNTY, Colo. — A skier was rescued on Sunday after sliding up to 2,000 feet while attempting to descend Skywalker Couloir.
According to a release, at 10:37 a.m. Sunday, Boulder County Communications was notified of a skier who had sustained serious injuries in the area of Skywalker Couloir on South Arapahoe Peak west of Nederland.
The 47-year-old man was beginning a ski descent of the couloir when he fell, sliding and tumbling around 1,000 to 2,000 feet down on the snowfield before coming to a stop at a rock ledge.
Two off-duty firefighters recreating in the area witnessed the fall and were able to call 911, according to the release. They also descended to where the injured man had stopped and were able to provide first aid and relay information to the responding rescue teams.
According to the release, rescuers and medical personnel from Rocky Mountain Rescue Group were flown near the scene by MedEvac before climbing the rest of the way to the scene.
They were also assisted by other bystanders who helped carry equipment to the scene and additional rescuers hiked in from the Fourth of July Trailhead bringing additional equipment.
Rescuers were able to place the skier in a full-body vacuum splint, and he was hoisted from the scene and transported by helicopter to Nederland Middle and Senior High School. The skier was then transported by ambulance to a local hospital.
According to the release, the skier sustained serious injuries but “remained stable throughout the incident.”
Assisting agencies involved with this rescue effort include the Boulder County Sheriff’s Office, Boulder County Parks and Open Space, Nederland Fire Protection District, the Rocky Mountain Rescue Group, the Colorado Search and Rescue Association, the Colorado Hoist Rescue Team, MedEvac, and American Medical Response.
(c)2024 the Daily Camera (Boulder, Colo.)
Visit the Daily Camera (Boulder, Colo.) at www.dailycamera.com

Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

America’s Favorite Video Today After their unsuccessful trip to Auburn, the defending champions got the better of Alabama in front of 5,575 in attendance at the Coleman Coliseum and got their campaign back on track. LSU is back to winning ways ADVERTISEMENT Article continues below this ad The battle was head-to-head in the opening quarter, with LSU holding a slight lead. Following this, Alabama’s vibrant forward Aaliyah Nye went on a scoring spree and got the home team ahead in the closing minutes. Consequently, the Crimson Tide were a point ahead by the end of the first quarter. ADVERTISEMENT Article continues below this ad After this, Angel Reese tried to get the lead back for the Lady Tigers with the help of Flau’jae Johnson and Mikayla Williams. But the home team didn’t let their guard down. They remained in front of the back of Nye’s double-digit score. Eventually, despite a combined fightback from Reese and Johnson to get LSU on a 9-0 run, the contest ended 35-34 at half-time in favor of the home team. Sophomore guard Flau’jae Johnson soon joined her as LSU quickly found themselves in the driving seat. Apparently, they were 20-3 in the first 6 minutes of the third quarter. author: AutoGuide.com News Staff
title: Biden Announces New $1.7 Billion Grants For EV Production | AutoGuide.com
text: Biden Announces New $1.7 Billion Grants For EV Production [Share] The Biden administration is throwing nearly $2 billion at electric vehicle manufacturing and assembly sites across eight states, including the political battlegrounds of Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Georgia. The Energy Department will dish out $1.7 billion in grants, aiming to create or retain thousands of union jobs and breathe life back into communities dependent on auto manufacturing. Beyond the trio of battleground states, the cash will flow to EV facilities in Ohio, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, and Virginia. This is a broad sweep of the automotive supply chain, covering everything from parts for electric motorcycles and school buses to hybrid powertrains and heavy-duty truck batteries. It's a move that screams both economic rejuvenation and environmental crusade, wrapped in the kind of high-stakes political drama that's become all too familiar in recent years. The timing of this announcement isn't lost on anyone. Biden, at 81, is shaking off calls to step aside after a less-than-stellar debate performance, clinging to his agenda while critics circle. Former President Donald Trump, despite his felony conviction, still has a chokehold on the Republican Party. The political theater is as intense as ever. This influx of federal cash is just a piece of the puzzle. It complements $177 billion in private sector investment in EV and battery manufacturing since Biden took office. Officials stress that the grants come with strings attached: commitments to workers and communities must be met, and environmental reviews will be completed before any money changes hands. If everything goes according to plan, the projects funded by these grants will create over 2,900 jobs and secure about 15,000 union jobs across 11 facilities. Stellantis is set to receive almost $335 million to revamp an idled Illinois plant for EV assembly and another $250 million to convert an Indiana transmission plant to make electric drive modules. General Motors will grab $500 million to transform its Lansing, Michigan plant into an EV manufacturing facility. Ford will not receive any funds. This article was co-written using AI and was then heavily edited and optimized by our editorial team. Become an AutoGuide insider. Get the latest from the automotive world first by subscribing to our newsletter [here](https://email.autoguide.com/newsletter-signup/). More by [AutoGuide.com News Staff](/member/1/admin)

author: @newsmax
title: Meta Plans Standalone Artificial Intelligence App | Newsmax.com
text:
Thursday, 27 February 2025 04:37 PM EST
Meta Platforms plans to debut a standalone Meta AI app to join Facebook and Instagram during the second quarter, CNBC reported Thursday, citing people familiar with the matter.
The move marks a major step in Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg's plans to make Meta the leader in AI by the end of the year, ahead of competitors like OpenAI and Alphabet, CNCB reported.
Meta did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.
Last month, Zuckerberg said that the company plans to spend as much as $65 billion this year to expand its AI infrastructure.

author: @UnioneSarda
title: Banditi in fuga con 4 milioni - L'Unione Sarda.it
text:
Ci sono 15 banditi in fuga con 4 milioni di euro. Caccia all’uomo in tutta la Sardegna. Nel mirino c’è il commando armato che, mercoledì mattina, ha assaltato tre portavalori sulla 131, all’altezza di Siligo. Banditi che hanno pianificato nel dettaglio il blitz, grazie anche a qualche talpa. I sindacati lanciano l’allarme-sicurezza. Migliorano le condizioni dei cinque vigilantes feriti.
l alle pagine 2, 3
